conclusion: Understanding the geometry and angles of the semicircular glass brick.
The radius of the semicircular glass brick is R and the angle of incidence for the incoming light rays at the flat base is π/2 - γ.
The critical angle for total internal reflection within the glass is γ.
Refraction at the flat base will bend the rays towards the normal, following Snell's law.
Any ray that strikes the curved surface at an angle greater than the critical angle γ will undergo total internal reflection.
Identify rays that pass through the curved surface without total internal reflection.
The ray tangent to the curved surface at point E is crucial as it just grazes the surface and does not undergo total internal reflection.
The angle between the tangent at E and the radius OE is γ.
Consider triangle OEN where OE is perpendicular to the tangent at E and ∠OEN = π/2 - γ.
In triangle OEN, EN can be found using trigonometry: EN = R tan(γ).
The width through which light passes is twice EN because light symmetrically passes through both sides: Width = 2 × EN = 2R tan(γ).
The width of the portion of the base through which light passes is 2R tan(γ).
